definitions.definition: an activity that you do to have fun, often one that has rules and that you can win or lose; the equipment for a game

examples.text: The kids were **playing a game** with their balloons.
The children invented a new game.
a **video/computer game**
I play **online games** with my friends.
a **game of chance/skill**
Buy your games and software from us.
Children love learning new games.
Chess is a game of skill.
We are developing a new game to play on your phone.
It's hard to find indoor games for children.
This is a good game for getting people to mix.
children's party games like Musical Chairs
I have been an avid roleplaying game fan for more than 20 years.
competitive games in which there is always a winner and a loser
Millions of people buy racing games every year.

definitions.definition: a sport with rules in which people or teams compete against each other

examples.text: **ball games**, such as football or tennis
How I hated **team games** at school!
the game of golf/cricket/basketball
Broadcasters have injected vast amounts of money into the game of football.

definitions.definition: an occasion of playing a game
definitions.sensetop: a game of somethinggame against somebodygame with somebody
definitions.labels: (especially North American English)British English(North American English)

examples.text: to **win/lose a game**
They lost their first **home game** of the season.
a **baseball/basketball game**
a **football game**
We're going to the **ball game** *(= baseball game)*.
Are you coming to **watch the game**?
to **play a game** of chess
Let's **have a game of** table tennis.
Saturday’s League game against Swansea
today's game with Manchester United
They're in training for the **big game**.
The defence are coming under pressure for the first time in this game.
their first League game of the season
United are playing a home game this week.
The team fought back to level the game.
The early stages of the game were dominated by the home team.
Last night he played the final game of his career.
It's going to be a close game.
He's hoping to be fit before next week's game with Liverpool.
Moeen Ali had a good game and was man of the match.
We won the first game and drew the second.
He pitched a perfect game at Atlanta.

definitions.definition: the way in which somebody plays a game

examples.text: Maguire **raised his game** to collect the £40 000 first prize.
Stretching exercises can help you avoid injury and improve your game.

definitions.definition: a large organized sports event

examples.text: She's hoping to participate in the next Olympic Games.
To stage the Games *(= the Olympic Games or a similar event)* is an honour.

definitions.definition: sport as a lesson or an activity at school

examples.text: I always hated games at school.

definitions.definition: a section of some games, such as tennis, which forms a unit in scoring

examples.text: two games all *(= both players have won two games)*
Zverev won the opening game of the third set.

definitions.definition: a type of activity or business

examples.text: How long have you been in this game?
the game of politics
I'm **new to this game** myself.
Getting dirty was **all part of the game** to the kids.
Lufthansa entered the game with a 25% stake in the company.
Predicting the outcome of the election is a game of chance.

definitions.definition: a secret and clever plan; a trick

examples.text: So **that's his game** *(= now I know what he has been planning)*.
He was unwittingly caught up in a dangerous game of lies and betrayals.
I realized that he had been playing a stupid game with me.
I'll soon put an end to her silly little games.

definitions.definition: wild animals or birds that people hunt for sport or food
at an advantage/disadvantage because you have done more/less preparation or know more/less than other people, especially those you are competing against

examples.text: We'll be able to extract insights out of the data that will enable us to stay ahead of the game.
Politicians are behind the game in understanding how fast the world is changing.

definitions.definition: to defeat or do better than somebody in an activity which they have chosen or in which they think they are strong
to not be considered to be serious

examples.text: For her the whole project was **just a game**.

definitions.definition: to be working as a prostitute
to no longer have a chance of winning a game or succeeding in an activity that you are taking part in
to still/once again have a good chance of winning a game or succeeding in an activity that you are taking part in

examples.text: The team was still in the game, just one goal down.
He’s been fighting to get the struggling company back in the game.

definitions.definition: activities that are not serious and that other people may think are bad

examples.text: Teaching isn't all fun and games, you know.

definitions.definition: said to somebody who has done something wrong, when they are caught and the crime or trick has been discovered

examples.text: Maggie knew that he had recognized her and the game was up.

definitions.definition: used after something has happened that makes it clear that a contest is not yet decided and anyone could still win

examples.text: We were losing 2–0 with ten minutes to go, and then we scored. It was game on!

definitions.definition: used to say that it is no longer possible for somebody/something to succeed, survive or continue

examples.text: Given her recent slump in form, it might be game over already this season.
This technology could mean game over for gasoline-powered vehicles.
The slightest mistake and it's game over for him.

definitions.definition: to tell a secret, especially by accident; to show something that should be kept hidden

examples.text: Don't let him talk to anybody or he'll give the game away.

definitions.definition: an activity that is unlikely to be successful or make a profit
the most important aspect of an activity; the most important quality needed for an activity

examples.text: Hard work is the name of the game if you want to succeed in business.

definitions.definition: the advantages to be gained from doing something are not great enough, considering the effort or cost involved

examples.text: If the price goes up again, he may decide that the game’s not worth the candle.

definitions.definition: a way of considering an activity, etc. that considers only the number of people doing something, things achieved, etc., not with who or what they are

examples.text: MPs were playing the numbers game as the crucial vote drew closer.

definitions.definition: performing badly/well, especially when compared with how well you usually perform

examples.text: He was off his game and missed two early penalties.

definitions.definition: the most important thing of a particular type, or the only thing that is available
to play a cruel game with somebody in your power by changing your behaviour very often, so that they become nervous and do not know what to expect

examples.text: He thought the police were playing some elaborate game of cat and mouse and waiting to trap him.
Young car thieves enjoy playing cat and mouse with the police.

definitions.definition: to do something that helps somebody else’s plans, especially by accident, when you did not intend to help them
to behave in a fair and honest way

examples.text: You can’t do that—it’s not playing the game!

definitions.definition: to not be honest with somebody, especially in order to gain an advantage over them

examples.text: Don't play silly games with me; I know you did it.

definitions.definition: the standards of behaviour that most people accept or that actually operate in a particular area of life or business
(to have) a personal interest in an organization or activity, and therefore in its success

examples.text: When management and unions sit down at the negotiating table, both sides have skin in the game.
The neutral fan with no skin in the game can just sit back and enjoy the spectacle.

definitions.definition: to talk in a way that sounds convincing, but may not be sincere

examples.text: The senior managers talk a good game about customer relations, but really they don't care about the customer.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody who has played a trick on you that you can do the same thing to them
to improve the level at which you can compete, especially in a sport

examples.text: She's really upped her game since she joined the tennis club.
With these two snazzy new restaurants opening up, the other eating places in the area are going to have to up their game.

definitions.definition: used to ask why somebody is behaving as they are

wordOrigin: Old English gamen ‘amusement, fun’, gamenian ‘play, amuse oneself’, of Germanic origin.
